annotation.TEXT: Dust Crusher now fires out in a set arc, with the erupting pieces flying out like Dust Man's own version. It's easily one of the most powerful weapons in the game as well, as it can generally take out almost any enemy or mini-boss with one shot - mostly since all the exploding pieces have a chance of connecting if you fire it close enough. The only downside is that one-shot-on-screen limit is still applied, making it rough if you miss your mark in this high speed hack.

Time for the basic run-down: From Burst Chaser's mechanics, Mega Man is capable of moving and firing very fast in this hack, along with being able to jump much further. From Air Sliding, you gain the ability to do just that: slide while in the air. You only get one slide per jump or whenever you're off the ground in general. This means you can actually execute an air-slide after falling off the edge of a platform (even if you were sliding in the process).

Aside from his weakness affiliation and color palette, Bright Man doesn't seem to be any different. I have a feeling this will probably get updated in future versions, though hopefully Tsukikuro has plans for more extensive modifications to him when compared to the other bosses.

Ring Boomerang now has a "lagging" effect, where it pauses briefly at set intervals while it returns to you. While this can be helpful for dealing out multiple hits to larger targets, it suffers a similar problem to Dust Crusher in that you can still only have one on-screen at a time. Given that it can take a while for it to come back to you, it can become more of a hassle than anything.

Almost all of the enemies have been modified in some way as well. Some of the core stage gimmicks were changed to a lesser extent (such as Dust Man's crushing presses only receiving a minor speed increase), but there's still a few notable differences in some cases.

Skull Man now throws his shield at you, rather than simply removing it and walking towards you. Beyond that, he's roughly the same as he was before. Then again, he's also weak to the Flash Stopper now - which actually makes him even easier than while using it on the original Pharaoh Man.

One hack that falls into this category is "Rockman 4: Burst Chaser X Air Sliding," and it plays out exactly how you would imagine. This is actually a recently released hack by Tsukikuro, the same one that brought us the Rockman Claw series. Seeing his name should mean two things: Aside from having some neat mechanics (and a strange color palette), you know right away this hack is going to have an awesome soundtrack as well.
Rush Marine moves much faster in general, though more-so when you're going horizontal. Either way, it's not going to be used much (if at all) in this run.

Skull Barrier was given a slight buff with its damage output, along the added ability to fire it out in whichever direction you're facing. It still flakes out after one hit, but now that it's capable of killing a good amount of enemies on-contact, it's useful for countering any inevitable collisions with them.

Dust Man isn't all that different from his original version (which could actually be applied to almost all the bosses in this game). His Dust Crusher is now fired out at various arcs, with the 4 pieces that break from it now erupting at impact with the ground and at a closer range, rather than a crossed pattern. The initial projectile itself can also bounce off walls.
The Wire is virtually the same as it was in the original. Either way, much like Rush Marine, it doesn't have much use in this hack outside of a few completely optional situations.

Flash Stopper seems to have gotten a slight nerf in this hack. It now has 6 uses instead of 7, and you can only have one shot on-screen at any given time while it's active. It also seems to last less time in general (roughly 4 seconds), but given this hack's emphasis on speed, I can sort of understand the mentality behind this change.

It's finally time to get back to some familiar territory, and with a few (potentially familiar) twists in the process. It seems like it's been a while since I've played through a Mega Man hack, rather than a stand-alone fan game. Although there's plenty to choose from, there's very few that manage to grab my attention from the title alone.

Ring Man follows roughly the same pattern as he did in the original, only now he'll throw his second ring down to catch you if you slide under him. He'll also occasionally throw a third ring as he's walking, but either way, he's actually very easy to avoid overall.

For those of you that have never seen or heard of the two other hacks that this game draws its mechanics off of, I'll elaborate as this goes on. It's also worth noting that the basis for the combination of these two hacks is essentially the game directly in the middle of them (Burst Chaser was an MM3 hack, and Air Sliding was a hack of MM5).

Oh, and it's here that I finally remembered that you can quick-switch between weapons by pressing select. While it's definitely handy, I guess I'd just need more time to get used to it over the more traditional forms of quick-switching.
